metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central, Calcutta v. Messrs. Gold Mohore Investment Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee Company is a dealer in shares and values stocks at cost at opening and closing.
In assessment year 1949-50 (previous year ending 31st March 1949), Assessee held 2,500 shares of Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. of face value Rs.10 each, purchased at Rs.85 per share, total cost Rs.2,12,500.
In June 1948, Howrah Mills issued bonus shares in proportion of three shares for every two original shares, ranking pari passu; Assessee obtained 3,750 bonus shares of face value Rs.10 each.
On August 2, 1948, Assessee sold the original 2,500 shares for Rs.72,087/8 (about Rs.29 per share).
On March 18, 1949, Assessee sold 3,750 bonus shares for Rs.95,250 (Rs.25 per share).

Assessee computed loss of Rs.84,041/12 by taking cost of bonus shares as face value Rs.37,500, crediting profit on bonus Rs.95,250 - Rs.37,500 and setting off against loss on original shares Rs.2,12,500 - Rs.72,087/8; bonus shares included in trading account.
Income-tax Officer rejected Assessee's method, computed loss at Rs.46,541/12/0 treating bonus shares cost at Nil.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order; Tribunal accepted ITO's method of valuation.

In assessment year 1950-51 (previous year 1949-50), Assessee held 122 first preference shares of Fort Gloster Jute Company Ltd. costing Rs.22,883/12/-; received 137 second preference bonus shares of face value Rs.100 each.
Assessee sold 125 second preference shares for Rs.14,500, left with 122 first pref and 12 second pref; returned profit Rs.1,997 taking bonus cost at face value Rs.13,700 plus minor charge Rs.3.
Income-tax Officer spread cost of Rs.23,883/12 over 122 first pref and 137 second pref (average Rs.92/3/6 per share), computed profit Rs.2,973.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal confirmed ITO's assessment.

Tribunal referred questions to Calcutta High Court: For 1949-50, whether assessee can add Rs.37,500 face value of bonus shares as cost for loss in Howrah Mills shares; for 1950-51, whether can add Rs.13,700 face value for profit in Fort Gloster shares.
Calcutta High Court on August 27, 1963 held in favour of Assessee following its earlier decision in ITR 54/1960 and Patna HC in Dalmia Investment (41 ITR 705).

legal_issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances herein stated the assessee carrying on share dealing business, can add Rs. 37,500 being the face value of bonus shares issued to it free of cost on the basis of its old share-holding, as cost of its share holding for the purpose of determining loss in dealing in Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. shares? (1949-50)

Whether in the facts and circumstances herein stated, the assessee carrying on share dealing business, can add Rs. 13,700 being the face value of bonus shares issued to it free of cost on the basis of its old share holdings, as cost of its share holding for the purposes of determining profit in dealing in Fort Gloster Jute Co. shares? (1950-51)

petitioner_arguments.text: The method adopted by the Income-tax Officer is correct: where shares are pari passu and valuation at cost, spread price of original shares over old and new shares, average cost for profit/loss calculation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. (52 I.T.R. 567, SC reversing Patna HC); CIT Central Calcutta v. Gold Mohore Investment Co. Ltd. (68 I.T.R. 213)

petitioner_arguments.text: Patna HC decision (41 ITR 705) followed by Calcutta HC was reversed by SC; Calcutta HC erred.

respondent_arguments.text: Cost of bonus shares should be taken at face value for computing profit/loss.

court_reasoning.text: Four methods considered in Dalmia: (1) face value for bonus; (2) nil for bonus (ITO in Howrah); (3) spread original cost over all shares (average); (4) attribute fall in price to bonus. Correct method for pari passu bonus shares is third: spread original cost over original and bonus shares.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Method in Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. is correct.

court_reasoning.text: Emerald Co. Ltd. did not decide valuation of unsold bonus shares fully; difference trivial (Rs.18), no departure from cost method as original shares sold.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Emerald not approving alternative method; possible error in stating Tribunal's method.

court_reasoning.text: Method for Fort Gloster follows approved spread-over approach.

holdings.text: Correct method is to spread cost of original shares over original and bonus shares collectively to arrive at average cost per share for profit/loss computation where bonus shares rank pari passu.
Same rule applies to second assessment year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalmia Investment Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed by Calcutta HC but reversed by SC

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved third method of spreading cost over old and bonus shares

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta v. Gold Mohore Investment Co. Ltd.
Emerald Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Did not fully decide bonus valuation as shares unsold; trivial difference

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals of the Commissioner, set aside Calcutta High Court judgment, restored Tribunal's acceptance of Income-tax Officer's method of spreading original share cost over old and bonus shares for valuation at cost.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeals allowed in favour of Revenue

key_quotes.text: "the correct method to apply in cases where bonus shares rank pari passu is to follow the third method, namely, to take the cost of the original shares and to spread it over all the original as well as the bonus shares and to find out the average price of all the shares."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We have considered the matter once again and are of opinion that the method followed in the Dalmias case is the correct method"
key_quotes.speaker: court
